chunks.chunk_text: And we'll be hearing from a philosopher who believes the problem is not about trust itself but about trustworthiness – the ability to be trusted as being honest and reliable.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Of course, telling lies and lacking trustworthiness is nothing new – just think of the Trojan horse used to trip the ancient Greeks.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: OK Rob, we'll come back to that later. Society can't function without trust. So, does that mean the more trust the better?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Well, not according to philosopher Onora O'Neill. Here he is speaking to David Edmonds, presenter of the BBC World Service programme, The Big Idea.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: If you don't judge who is trustworthy and who is not, you are trusting to luck – simply believing or hoping that things will happen for the best.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: So, if indiscriminately trusting people is such a bad idea, how do we avoid it? How can we tell who is trustworthy and who is not? Here's the BBC World Service's Big Idea presenter, David Edmonds, asking Onora O'Neill to give some details.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: That's the boring one. That's just being honest and competent each time so that it's not enough to be episodically honest and competent for some of the things you claim to be able to do but not others.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: And you wouldn't trust your dentist to fix your broken down car either. Onora O'Neill also mentions reliability – being trustworthy because you behave well all the time and keep all the promises you make.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: It's the combination of these three – being honest, competent and reliable – that makes someone truly trustworthy. And not someone like Bernie Madoff, who would run off with your money and entire life savings. All of which brings me to my quiz question. Do you remember, Rob? Yeah, I do. You asked how much Bernie Madoff stole from the American investors he lied to. And I said B, $65 million. But in fact it was C, $65 billion – a lot of money to give
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: to such an untrustworthy man. So, we've been discussing whether there is a crisis of trust and asking how to know who is trustworthy – able to be trusted as honest, competent and reliable. Placing your trust in someone trustworthy is very different from being gullible – easy to trick because you trust and believe people too quickly. And it can also be unhelpful to trust things to luck – simply hope or believe that everything will work out for the best.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: But luckily there are many trustworthy people around and we can spot them using three criteria – honesty – in other words, not lying – competence and reliability.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Is this the era of distrust_.json

chunks.chunk_text: Just being honest and competent all the time – not just being honest sometimes or reliable in some actions, but not others. That's all for 6 Minute English. Bye for now. Bye bye.
